p.seg: Discourses of Master Zhong, Volume 1
Master Wenzhong said:
How difficult!
The Way of the True King is difficult to practice.
Our family has resided in Tongchuan for six generations.
We have never failed to be devoted to this [Way].
Yet, we have never been able to fully implement it.
Retiring, they all had writings to express
their understanding of the Way.
The writings of the first ancestor
are titled "Discourses on the Transformation of the Times," in six chapters.
In them, the principles of transforming customs and promoting change are thoroughly explored.
The writings of the Prefect of Jiangzhou
are titled "Resolutions on the Five Classics," in five chapters.
In them, the intentions of the sages and worthies in their creations and writings are fully elucidated.
The writings of Duke Mu of Jinyang
are titled "Discourses on Major Governance," in eight chapters.
In them, the Way of emperors and kings is clearly described.
The writings of the Prefect of Tongzhou
are titled "Discourses on Minor Governance," in eight chapters.
In them, the accomplishments of true kings and hegemons are fully explained.
The writings of Duke Xian of Ankang
are titled "Upright Commentary on the Imperial Ultimate," in nine chapters.
In them, the movements and inclinations of the Three Powers (Heaven, Earth, and Man) are profoundly explored.
The writings of the Prefect of Tongchuan
It is said that the seven chapters of "Essential Discourses on Rise and Fall"
clearly explain the successes and failures of the Six Dynasties.
I, a humble junior, have had the good fortune to see these instructive teachings,
and have diligently studied them for nine years.
I adhere to the principles of my ancestors,
examine the heart of Zhongni (Confucius),
and study the affairs of Heaven and humanity,
and the way of emperors and kings.
Are they not abundantly clear?
The Master said to Dong Chang:
"I wish to revise the *Yuan Jing*,"
"but examining various historical treatises,
they are insufficient to provide evidence.
I have obtained *Huangji Dangyi*."
"I wish to continue the *Book of Poetry*,"
"but examining various collected records,
they are insufficient to provide evidence.
I have obtained *Shi Bian Lun*."
"I wish to continue the *Book of Documents*,"
"but examining various recorded texts,
they are insufficient to provide evidence.
I have obtained *Zheng Da Lun*."
Dong Chang said:
"The Master's acquisitions
are indeed due to his ambition."
The Master said:
Agreed.
The Master said to Xue Shou:
"In the past, the sages, when they narrated history, did so in three ways:
When they narrated the *Book of Documents*,
the institutions of emperors and kings were fully provided,
therefore, if one searched it, one could always find them;
when they narrated the *Book of Poetry*,
the reasons for rise and fall were made evident,
therefore, if one investigated it, one could always understand them;
when they narrated the *Spring and Autumn Annals*,
the traces of what is correct and what is wicked were made clear,
therefore, if one examined it, one could always judge correctly.
These three,
all come from history
but cannot be mixed together.
Therefore, the sages distinguished them."
Master Wenzhong said:
"When I look at the writings since Sima Qian and Ban Gu,
why are they so numerous and chaotic?
Is the Way of emperors and kings obscure and unclear?
Is the intention of Heaven and Man
blocked and not communicated?
Are the principles of governance diverse and not unified?
Is the presentation of events disordered and without a thread?"
The Master was not feeling well. Upon hearing that there was unrest in Jiangdu,
With tears in his eyes, he rose and said:
"The people have long been weary of turmoil.
Perhaps Heaven is about to initiate an era like that of Yao and Shun.
I will not participate in it;
it is fate."
Master Wenzhong said:
"The Dao has long been unable to overcome the times.
What shall I do?"
Dong Chang said:
"Master, since you returned to Jin from Qin,
and resided in Fenyang,
then the Three Powers (Heaven, Earth, and Man) and the Five Constant Virtues
have each found their proper place."
Xue Shou said:
"May I ask why the continuation of the *Book of History* begins with the Han?"
The Master said:
"The evils of the Six Kingdoms
and the cruelty of the fall of Qin
are things I cannot bear to hear.
How could I draw from them the proper principles for an emperor?
The Han, in ruling the world,
eliminated the remnants of evil
and began anew with the people,
and stimulated their sight and hearing."
Xue Shou said:
"May I ask why the continuation of the *Book of Poetry* includes the Six Dynasties?"
The Master said:
"Because it begins with the *Three Hundred Poems* of Zhongni (Confucius), which began and ended with the Zhou?"
Shou said:
"Which of the three comes first?"
The Master said:
"The three powers (Heaven, Earth, and Man) cannot be separated.
When put into practice in affairs,
there must be a primary focus.
The round altar (for Heaven) values sacrifice,
for observing the ways of the spirits;
the square pool (for Earth) values libation,
for examining the categories of things;
the ancestral temple uses the Feast ritual,
for cherishing essential vital energy."
Shou said: "May I ask about the inner meanings of the three powers?"
The Master said:
Sublime indeed is your question!
Heaven,
it governs the primal qi,
it is not merely the boundless blue;
Earth,
it governs the primal form,
it is not merely mountains, rivers, hills, and mounds;
Man,
he governs the primal consciousness,
he is not merely a round head and square feet.
The essence of Qian and Kun (Heaven and Earth),
have you pondered it?
Thereupon Shou withdrew and studied the *Book of Changes* (*Yi Jing*).
The Master said:
"Archery was used to observe virtue;
this is now lost."
In ancient times, people valued benevolence and righteousness and
despised courage and strength.
The Master said:
"To abandon virtue and turn one's back on righteousness,
yet worry that people are not intimate with you;
to be fond of suspicion and to value deceit,
yet worry that people do not trust you—
such a thing is bound to happen."
The Master said:
"The superior man wins people's hearts,
not their words;
to win people's words,
but not their allegiance.
To win people's allegiance
is to force them with strength."
"The superior man uses righteousness;
the inferior man uses strength.
How difficult it is!"
The Master said:
"After the era of Tai Xi,
what remained of the Son of Heaven was merely the title."
Alas!
If one seeks to transform the masses by governing with regulations,
then the feudal lords will be compared to them.
Why is the *Yuan Jing* (a classic) not flourishing?
Fang Xuanling said to Xue Shou,
"That the Way will not be practiced is inevitable.
Why do you strive so busily?"
Xue Shou replied,
"Are you not a follower of the Master (Confucius)?
When the Son of Heaven loses the Way,
then the feudal lords cultivate it;
when the feudal lords lose the Way,
then the high officials cultivate it;
when the high officials lose the Way,
then the scholars cultivate it;
when the scholars lose the Way,
then the common people cultivate it.
The way to cultivate it
is to learn from teachers without fixed adherence,
to instruct without weariness,
to be impoverished without engaging in corrupt practices,
and to cease only after death.
If the time is right, then act;
if the time is not right, then lie dormant.
This is how the Way of the former kings is continued without decline,
and in ancient times it was called 'succeeding to the times.'
Does the *Book of Odes* not say,
Even if I do not go,
should you not continue his legacy?
How can you fail to act and let it be abandoned?
Xuanling, alarmed, apologized and said:
Is its practice so far-reaching?
*Zhong Shuo*, Volume 9
Is this not the correct explanation?
Wei Zheng, upon retiring, said to Xue Shou:
"The opportune time can be known."
Xue Shou asked:
"Why do the people of today not have poetry?"
You (respectful form of "he," referring back to Wei Zheng, but implying the gravity of a master) said:
"Poetry is
the feelings and nature of the people.
Can feelings and nature cease to exist?
It is not that the people have no poetry;
it is the fault of those whose duty it is to record poetry."
Yao Yi was distressed by poverty.
Fang Xuanling said:
"Alas,
his poverty!
Why not ask for help?"
Yao Yi said:
"In ancient times, people regarded even asking for help for others
as a relinquishing of something,
how much more so for oneself?
I do not wish it."
You (again implying Wei Zheng as a master) heard of this and said:
"How steadfast, the righteousness of Yi!
He truly practices the Way of the ancients,
and it has inspired me:
difficult to advance, easy to retreat."
The Master said:
Even in the most commonplace sayings, there must be something worth observing;
to seek the root, then it goes far.
Wang Gui asked his son to seek the "Continuation of the Classics."
The Master said: Uncle,
what virtue does Tong possess to do this?
Gui said:
Do not decline.
When it comes to practicing benevolence, one should not yield even to one's teacher;
how much less to one who is not a teacher?
I have heard of Guan Lang's divination:
after a period of accumulated chaos,
a great sage will surely be born.
In the world, regarding familiarity with the *Rites* and *Music*,
none are better than our clan.
Heaven has not yet abandoned the Way.
To revive this culture,
who is it if not you?
Wei Zheng asked:
What about governing matters by regulations?
How is that?
The Master said:
If the foundation is rectified,
punishments will be put aside.
If the Way is lost,
What benefit is there in discussion?
Therefore, in an age of utmost order,
laws are displayed but not violated;
next, they are violated but not frequently.
Therefore, discussing matters to create laws
alas! is the way of a middling age.
If someone were to employ me,
surely there would be no lawsuits, would there?
Master Wen Zhong said:
After pacifying Chen,
the dragon's virtue was at its height,
and yet in the end, he did not repent.
How sad!
The Master said:
In my 《Continuation of the Book》and 《Original Canon》,
is it knowing and writing about the Mandate of Heaven?
Grieving for the loss of rites and music, I record chapters and intentions;
to rectify the calendrical cycles, I distinguish between North and South;
Moved by the imperial system, I begin with the Taixi era;
honoring the Central Kingdom, I correct the Huangshi era.
Master Wen Zhong said:
In action, one errs by excess;
in stillness, one errs by deficiency.
The Master said:
There is no greater fault than loving to advance (oneself),
no greater disaster than excessive talk,
no greater pain than not hearing of one's faults,
no greater shame than not knowing shame.
The Master said:
"The sons of the Son of Heaven, when they come of age, gather for discussions about their fiefs, and when they understand governance, they receive office. This is the ancient way."
Xue Shou asked Zhongchang Zigang about government.
Zigang said:
"Raise one cord (of the net),
and all the eyes will open;
loosen one mechanism,
and all affairs will collapse."
(If you) do not know this, (you) do not know government.
Shou told Wenzhongzi.
The Master said:
"Zigang has gotten it."
Wenzhongzi said:
"Without knowing the Dao,
one cannot be a minister,
how much less a ruler?"
The Master said:
"If people do not live in neighborhoods (ordered by li),
and land is not received based on the well-field system,
it will ultimately lead to a makeshift way."
Even Shun and Yu could not manage it.
The Master said:
"If governance is harsh,
it is better to be kind;
if laws are strict,
it is better to be lenient;
if lawsuits are numerous,
it is better to be simple;
in the relationship between minister and ruler,
when suspicion arises, it is better to have trust.
Can one who adheres to the middle course
only be a sage?"
The Master said:
"If entrusting responsibility is inconsistent,
it is a harbinger of chaos;
if surveillance is incessant,
it is a breeding ground for treachery."
Pei Xi heard this and said:
"If those on the left and right suspect each other,
is that not chaos?
If superiors and inferiors spy on each other,
is that not treachery?
The ancients called this the governance of snakes and pigs.
Alas!
This is the crime that led to the downfall of Qin."
Du Yan asked about reclusion.
The Master said:
It is not that they conceal their bodies and cannot be seen,
but when the times and fate are greatly disordered, they conceal their virtue.
Only those who possess the Way can do this.
Therefore, it is called retreating and storing oneself in secret.
Du Yan said:
With the rise of the *Book of Changes*,
is the world perhaps something to be doubted?
Therefore, is it that sages are able to conceal themselves?
The Master said:
To manifest benevolence and conceal utility [or function],
this is a matter of the middle ages.
Yan said:
May I venture to ask about the meaning of concealment?
The Master said:
Erase one's tracks,
unfold one's mind,
and one can understand spiritually,
but it is difficult to seek through affairs.
This is the meaning of it.
He further asked about the essence of the Way.
The Master said:
Do not move unless it is in accordance with ritual,
do not look unless it is in accordance with ritual,
do not listen unless it is in accordance with ritual.
Yan said:
This is the eye of the benevolent.
Confucius said:
"The Way is within it."
Yan Tui said to Ru Hui:
"Looking at it, it's in front,
suddenly, it's behind."
Truly, Master Yan knew it.
Master Wen Zhong said:
"If the four classes of people are not distinct,
the five ranks are not established,
the six offices are not properly filled,
the nine regions are not ordered,
then the great writings and standards of the emperors of antiquity will not be understood.
If the world is not governed by the laws of the Three Dynasties,
it will ultimately be a state in peril.
If there is no alternative,
then it should be the system of the Two Han dynasties?
If the world is not assisted by the system of the Two Han dynasties,
it will truly be in chaos."
Master Wen Zhong said:
"The expositions of Zhong Ni (Confucius)
are vast, comprehensive, and complete,
yet, after a thousand years, they are not put to use.
How sad!"
Qiu Zhang stepped forward and said:
"But why is Master now so diligent in expounding them?"
The Master said:
"The duties of the former teachers
I dare not abandon.
How can we know that later generations cannot make use of them?
If the weeds are cleared and the grass grows luxuriantly,
then there will be a bountiful year."
The Master said to Xue Shou:
"Since the decline of the Northern Wei,
the world has had no true ruler.
In the ninth year of Kaihuang (Sui Dynasty),
people began to be unified.
My ancestors had a saying:
'Respecting one's duties begins with emphasizing the beginning,
and being cautious of one's position starts with rectifying one's name.'
This is why I made suggestions during the Renshou era.
Your Majesty is a true emperor,
do not follow false and chaotic precedents,
you must emulate the Zhou and Han dynasties.
"Use earth to overcome fire,
venerate the color yellow,
and use the number five.
Discard the methods of the four previous dynasties,
to accord with the Mandate of Heaven.
This is a once-in-a-thousand-years opportunity,
that must not be missed."
Emperor Gaozu esteemed his words but could not use them.
The reason for this is
I aspire to emulate the deeds of the Duke of Zhou.
Therefore, among the "Twelve Strategies," what should come first?
It must be that which rectifies the beginning.
Wei Yong was appointed magistrate of Longmen.
Upon arriving, he immediately expanded the government building.
Master (文中子) heard of this and said:
"This is not what should be done first.
You are tiring the people to benefit yourself.
How can you be concerned with this?"
Yong immediately stopped the work to apologize to the Master.
The Master said:
"Without diligence and frugality,
one cannot lead others."
Disciples Dou Wei, Jia Qiong, and Yao Yi received instruction in the *Li* (Book of Rites);
Wen Yanbo, Du Ruhui, and Chen Shuda received instruction in the *Yue* (Book of Music);
Du Yan, Fang Qiao, and Wei Zheng received instruction in the *Shu* (Book of Documents);
Li Jing, Xue Fangshi, Pei Xi, and Wang Gui received instruction in the *Shi* (Book of Poetry);
Shu Tian received instruction in the *Yuan Jing* (an astronomical text);
Dong Chang, Qiu Zhang, Xue Shou, and Cheng Yuanbei heard the meaning of the Six Classics.
Ning Chang heard:
"One who does not specialize in a classic
should not dare to receive instruction in it."
Since each classic had its own specific explanations,
therefore I record it here.
The Prefect of Taiyuan said:
The teachings of Master Wenzhong
must be promulgated.
Time passes like the sun and moon,
we must not let the descendants of Master Wenzhong be ignorant of these things.
He summoned his three sons and taught them the *Lüe Li* (Outline Examples).
The Prefect of Taiyuan was named Ning.
He behaved properly
with utmost respect,
his sons and younger brothers would not see him unless he was properly attired in formal clothing.
Within the confines of his household, it was as solemn as the imperial court.
Master Wenzhong of old said:
A worthy man
is one who is composed and upright,
flexible judgment may be lacking,
but he is fit to stand on his own.
The Prefect bowed twice and said:
I respectfully accept your instruction.
He never acted without propriety throughout his life.
During the Zhenguan era,
he began his career as a Supervising Censor,
accusing Marquis Junji of harboring disloyal intentions.
And when he retired,
his hometown community was at peace because of his virtue.
He managed his household with four teachings:
Diligence, frugality, respect, and forgiveness;
to regulate the family with the four rites:
capping (coming-of-age ceremony), marriage, funerals, and sacrifices.
If there is enough savings for three years,
then distribute it among relatives.
The books of sages and official ceremonial regalia are not borrowed.
Walls, houses, and miscellaneous items must be strong and simple,
saying, "Do not be carelessly extravagant";
gates, lanes, fruits and trees must be arranged in an orderly fashion,
saying, "Do not be carelessly disordered."
He treated his widowed sister-in-law with renowned respect and obedience.
He did not deceive or be devious with people,
and did not accept gifts.
If it was not by his own effort,
and not by his official salary,
he would never eat or wear it.
The rituals of banquets do not add extra things,
saying, "Reaching the level of ritual is enough";
at home he did not eat meat,
saying, "Do not seek to be full";
one cloth quilt lasted for twenty years without being changed,
saying, "Do not waste the resources of the world."
If the villagers falsely accused him of owing taxes,
he would pay them twice in one year,
and as an official, he would accept his salary based on the number of days worked.
Even past the age of seventy,
His hands never stopped holding the scriptures.
If relatives or friends did something unjust,
he would certainly correct them,
saying: "Praising to one's face but slandering behind one's back,
I cannot bear to do that."
When in a group and speaking freely,
he never mentioned the shortcomings of others.
He always had an unapproachable demeanor,
therefore petty people stayed far away from him.
Du Yan said, "Will the *Continuing Classics* be put into practice?"
The Taiyuan Prefect said:
"The most urgent thing for princes, dukes, and great men.
The Way of the former kings,
is laid out within it.
When the world has the Way,
the sage promotes it and puts it into practice;
when the world lacks the Way,
the sage elaborates on it and stores it away.
As it is said, 'If you let it flow, it becomes a river;
if you block it, it becomes a deep pool.'
Ascending, it becomes clouds;
spreading, it becomes rain;
when hidden, it moistens;
in what direction is it not beneficial?"
The Taiyuan Prefect said:
The Master gained Cheng, Qiu, Dong, and Xue, and the Six Classics became even clearer.
The creation of the *Dui Wen* (Dialogues and Questions)
is due to the efforts of these four students.
Dong and Qiu died early,
and Cheng and Xue soon followed.
The teachings of Master Wen Zhong
had yet to be compiled.
Alas!
We await the coming of wise men.
Preface
The teachings of Master Wen Zhong
continue the Way of the Uncrowned King (Confucius),
therefore the "Way of the King" chapter is placed first.
The ancient sage kings,
in their every action conformed their virtue to the two powers of Heaven and Earth,
therefore the "Heaven and Earth" chapter is placed next.
When Heaven is honored and Earth is humbled,
the relationship between ruler and minister is established,
therefore the "Serving the Ruler" chapter is placed next.
In serving the ruler, one should follow the model of Heaven,
and no one is better than the Duke of Zhou,
therefore the "Duke of Zhou" chapter is placed next.
The Way of the Duke of Zhou
is found, perhaps divinely, within the *Book of Changes*,
therefore the "Inquiring about the Changes" chapter is placed next.
The *Book of Changes*
is the origin of teachings and transformations.
Nothing is greater for teachings and transformations than ritual and music,
Therefore, it is followed by the "Rituals and Music" chapter.
When rituals and music are extensively documented and clearly manifested, then it becomes history.
Therefore, it is followed by the "Narrating History" chapter.
Establishing literature and establishing institutions,
harmonious governance is paramount.
Only Wei Xiang possessed this.
Therefore, it is followed by the "Wei Xiang" chapter.
When Yin and Yang are harmonized,
then the principle of nature is understood.
Exhaustively investigating principle and fulfilling nature leads to understanding destiny.
Therefore, it is followed by the "Establishing Destiny" chapter.
Who other than the *Book of Changes* can attain to the explanation of nature and destiny?
Only the *Book of Changes*.
Guan Zi,
is a profound scholar of the *Book of Changes*.
Therefore, it is followed by the "Guan Lang" chapter, which concludes the book.
Master Wenzhong,
of the Wang family,
personal name Tong,
courtesy name Zhongyan.
His ancestor was the Han recluse Ba,
who maintained his purity and did not serve in office.
The eighteenth-generation ancestor Yin,
was the Grand Administrator of Yunzhong,
and settled in Qi.
He used the *Spring and Autumn Annals* and the *Book of Changes* to instruct the local community,
as a resource for his descendants.
The fourteenth-generation ancestor Shu,
He was able to carry on the achievements of his ancestors.
He wrote the "Meaning and System of the Spring and Autumn Annals."
He was recommended by the ducal court, but he declined to serve.
His ninth-generation ancestor, Yu,
encountered the disasters of Emperors Min and Huai,
and consequently moved east.
Yu begat Han.
Han begat Xiu.
Both became famous for their literary talent.
Xiu begat two sons,
the elder named Xuanmo,
the younger named Xuanze.
Xuanmo rose in rank due to his military strategy,
Xuanze advanced due to his Confucian scholarship.
Xuanze, with the courtesy name Yanfa,
was the sixth-generation ancestor of Master Wenzhong.
He served in the Song dynasty,
holding the positions of Grand Master of the Imperial Stud and Doctor of the Imperial Academy.
He often lamented, saying:
"What my late father valued was ritual and music;
what he disdained was military service.
What is my elder brother doing?"
Therefore, he deeply investigated morality,
studied the classics,
and said that meritorious achievements cannot be made in a small way.
Therefore, he ultimately became a great Confucian scholar.
High ministerial positions should not be held lightly.
Therefore, he ultimately remained a Doctor,
It is said to be the duty of the former teachers
that cannot be abandoned.
The gentleman,
who received their teachings, is called Mr. Wang's disciple.
Thus, he greatly extolled the Confucian school,
and the world benefited from its virtues.
The gentleman was born to Huan, the Prefect of Jiangzhou,
and Huan gave birth to Qiu.
Qiu first served the Wei Dynasty in the north,
and during the Taihe reign, he became the Governor of Bingzhou.
His family was from the He and Fen rivers,
and he was called Duke Mu of Jinyang.
Duke Mu gave birth to Yan, the Governor of Tongzhou,
who was called the Prefect of Tongzhou.
Yan gave birth to the Governor of Jizhou,
also known as Duke Xian of Ankang.
Duke Xian of Ankang gave birth to the Prefect of Tongchuan,
whose personal name was Long,
and his courtesy name was Bogao,
who was the father of Wenzhongzi.
He inherited the teachings of the gentleman
and taught more than a thousand disciples.
At the beginning of the Kaihuang era of the Sui Dynasty,
he was treated as a National Academy Erudite and awaited orders at Yunlong Gate.
At that time, the nation had just experienced abdication and yielding,
and was establishing the empire through respectfulness and frugality.
The Emperor leisurely said to the Prefect:
"What kind of ruler am I?"
The Prefect said:
"Your Majesty is intelligent and divinely martial,
endowed by Heaven.
When issuing decrees and commands,
you do not fully consult the ancients.
Although possessing the talents of Yao and Shun,
you will ultimately be burdened by a lack of learning."
The Emperor silently said:
"Sir, you are my Lu Jia.
What can you teach me?"
The Prefect, receiving the imperial command, composed seven chapters of "Essential Discourses on Rise and Fall."
Each time he presented them,
the Emperor praised them,
but did not fully understand them.
The Prefect went out to serve as Magistrate of Changle,
and was transferred to Yi'shi and Tongchuan.
His governance was renowned.
Upon completion of his term, he retired and returned home,
and never served again.
In the fourth year of the Kaihuang era,
Wenzhongzi was born.
The Prefect of Tongchuan divined his future,
obtaining the hexagram of "Kun" transforming into "Shi."
He presented the omen to Duke Xian of Ankang.
Duke Xian said:
"This is the hexagram of a Uncrowned King! Why does it come?
Earth, number two, transforms into Heaven, number one.
Possessing superior virtue while residing in a humble position,
If one can employ the multitude of the upright,
one can become a true king.
Even if one possesses the virtues of a ruler,
isn't it all about timing?
This child will surely be able to understand the aspirations of the world."
Thereupon, he named him Tong.
In the ninth year of the Kaihuang era
Jiangdong was pacified.
The Lord of Tongchuan Prefecture sighed and said:
"If the way of the true king is not established,
how can the world be unified?"
Master Wenzhong, who had been serving by his side for ten years,
with a worried expression, said:
"Tong has heard that
the ancient founders of states
had long-term strategies,
therefore, from the Xia and Yin dynasties downwards for hundreds of years,
the whole world was always unified.
Later founders of states
practiced expedient policies,
therefore, from the Wei and Jin dynasties downwards for hundreds of years,
the nine provinces had no fixed ruler.
When the ruler loses his way,
the people scatter for a long time.
One this way, one that way,
what permanence is there?
Master's sigh,
is probably worried that the imperial authority is not being upheld
Is the world about to descend into chaos?"
The Prefect of Tongchuan found it strange and said,
"Is that so?"
He then told him about the *Yuan Jing*.
Wenzhongzi bowed twice and accepted it.
In the eighteenth year,
the Prefect of Tongchuan was at leisure,
singing "Cutting Down the Trees" (from the *Book of Poetry*),
and summoned Wenzhongzi.
Wenzhongzi, startled, bowed twice:
"May I ask, Master, what is your intention?"
The Prefect of Tongchuan said,
"Come here!
From the Son of Heaven to the common people,
none can succeed without relying on friends.
Of the three meanings,
the teacher occupies one.
Since the Way has declined,
this has been abandoned for a long time.
But what is constant?
Strive, young man,
soar and then settle."
From then on, Wenzhongzi had ambitions for all directions.
He received the *Book of Documents* from Li Yu of the Eastern Sea,
studied the *Book of Poetry* with Xia Dian of Kuaiji,
inquired about the *Rites* from Guan Ziming of Hedong,
corrected his understanding of *Music* with Huo Ji of Beiping,
examined the *Book of Changes* with his paternal uncle Zhonghua,
At the age of six, he did not remove his clothes [for sleep];
